resources.string: The most common blood type is O, followed by type A. Type O individuals are often called \"universal donors\" since their blood can be transfused into persons with any blood type. Those with type AB blood are called universal recipients because they can receive blood of any type.

Blood Bank India\' is a product developed for a social welfare initiative so that nobody suffers due to blood unavailability.The need for blood is great - on any given day, approximately 39,000 units of Red Blood Cells are needed. Each year, they intend to meet upto to 1% (approx) of our nationâ€™s demand for blood transfusion. \n\n
Despite the increase in the number of donors, blood remains in short supply during emergencies, mainly attributed to the lack of information and accessibility. We positively believe this application could be a handy one and can overcome most of these challenges by effectively connecting the blood donors with the blood recipients.
